image.altText: An image purportedly of toppled Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro, posted by Donald Trump on Truth Social.

props.synopsis: The US has "captured" Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro and his wife during an early-morning raid, which saw US military strike targets within the capital Caracas and in several other states. Follow live.

title.children: Venezuela hit in US strikes

image.altText: Trump on stage in front of a US flag

props.synopsis: It is entirely fitting that the US is so splintered on its semiquincentennial. Division, for the lion's share of its history, has been its default.

title.children: America's 250th birthday party will serve up a toxic brew of exceptionalism

image.altText: A south Asian man and woman, both old, very sad, stand in front of a metal shack, hold a photo of man, a garland across it.

props.synopsis: Four Hindu men have been killed in Muslim-majority Bangladesh in just over two weeks, and several houses have been burned, leaving the minority community traumatised and fearing for their lives.

title.children: Hindus 'living in fear' after man's public lynching for alleged blasphemy

image.altText: A aerial image of floodwaters at Winton in Queensland.

props.synopsis: Tourists are stranded in towns dotted across north-west Queensland as rain continues to keep major rivers in flood.

title.children: Tourists stranded, dozens of roads closed as showers continue in outback Queensland

image.altText: Erskineville and Macdonaldtown 2025-11-25 11:11:00

props.synopsis: It's the suburb in Sydney that no longer exists — except for a train station — but did it disappear because of scandalous murders or was it just to increase property prices?

title.children: A station and infamous murders: What happened to Sydney's Macdonaldtown?

image.altText: Man in a suit speaking into a microphone behind a podium while holding up a chart

props.synopsis: From de minimis to beef tariffs, Aussie exporters are preparing for another "wild" year.

title.children: Australian brands still dealing with 'the wild west' of Trump's tariffs

image.altText: A man wearing a teal raincoat and helmet stands smiling on a fishing boat.

props.synopsis: The Japanese island of Etajima's oyster industry relies almost entirely on foreign workers due to its aging population.

title.children: Amid a population crisis, this island needs migrants to keep its industry alive

image.altText: Woman climbs snow section of mountains.

props.synopsis: Pakistani women are hiking some of the world's tallest mountains and glacier trails, claiming a space that has long been out of reach.

title.children: On Pakistan's roof of the world, a new generation of female climbers emerge

image.altText: A sign for Curragh mining complex in Central Queensland

props.synopsis: A worker has died after a roof collapse at the Curragh mining complex in Central Queensland.

title.children: Worker dies in Central Queensland mine following roof collapse

image.altText: A pile of pink and black books with titles like 'Love Unleashed' and 'Burn'.

props.synopsis: An anthology of love stories written by First Nations people is in the works with stories of blak love, joy, and connection capitalising on the fastest growing literary genre in the world.

title.children: Traditional romance stories get a First Nations twist with 'choc-lit'

image.altText: A photo of a double story long hotel, with green pillars and a white fence, with a steel gate surrounding it,in a country town,

props.synopsis: For the first time in almost 140 years, Toora's historic pub did not trade over the festive season, leaving locals and visitors with nowhere to drink.

title.children: Summer is here but this town's pub is closed for the first time in 140 years

image.altText: Brie cheese.

props.synopsis: An Adelaide retiree who continually ignored orders to remove an unauthorised backyard cheesemaking facility from his suburban home is ordered to pay more than $120,000 in costs, after being found guilty of contempt of court.

title.children: Man told to pay $120,000 over unauthorised backyard cheese business

image.altText: A person's hand buttering a slice of wholemeal bread with margarine

props.synopsis: You might have a personal preference for which spread you use at home, but experts say there are health considerations for which one you use.

title.children: Is butter, margarine or nut spread the best choice?

image.altText: A young man with dark facial hair.

props.synopsis: Police seek public assistance to locate a 22-year-old French man who allegedly sexually assaulted a woman in a Melbourne laneway in the early hours of New Year's Day.

title.children: Police seek help after alleged sexual assault in Melbourne laneway on January 1

image.altText: Alex de Minaur plays a forehand during a United Cup match.

props.synopsis: Alex de Minaur is not concerned about his Australian Open preparations, believing he can "flip that switch" after recording his first career defeat to Casper Ruud.

title.children: De Minaur unfazed by United Cup loss in Australian Open build-up

image.altText: black-and-white photo of a smiling Sir Edmund Hillary.

props.synopsis: Less than five years after conquering Mount Everest, legendary explorer Sir Edmund Hillary wanted to make history again in Antarctica.

title.children: How Hillary made history again with an 'arrogant' dash to the South Pole

image.altText: A city lit up with colourful lights at night

props.synopsis: Your task in the ABC Places quiz is to correctly identify the location shown in each of 10 photos. Grab your passport and let's go.

title.children: Quiz: How well do you know these places around the world?

image.altText: Two hands read braille notation in a white, spiral bound book. The torso of the reader is visible and they wear a red tshirt.

props.synopsis: In the 1820s, Louis Braille devised a raised-dot system of letters, numbers and musical notation. 200 years later, it’s still opening the music world for blind musicians.

title.children: How braille music opens up the music world for blind people

image.altText: A man with cropped hair and stubble smiling and looking out of frame

props.synopsis: Oliver Foran struggled with his mental health after losing his mother to cancer. Now, he is training to set a world record while raising money and awareness for youth mental health.

title.children: Brisbane man training to take on Mount Everest world record

image.altText: firefighters stand outside a home that was destroyed by fire at spring farm

props.synopsis: A man dies and two people are hospitalised after a fire at a home in Sydney's south-west overnight.

title.children: Man dies after ferocious fire at disability support home in south-west Sydney

image.altText: A girl with glasses has her left eye partially covered b a hand holding an eye shield

props.synopsis: A group of researchers is calling on the South Australian government to implement a universal vision screening program for all children attending preschools or day care centres.

title.children: Early eye testing helped Lucy avoid blindness

image.altText: Girl in a light blue shirt and helmet on a brown horse

props.synopsis: As the Tumbarumba Rodeo celebrates its 80th year, the Rial family have held on for the longest ride of them all.

title.children: Snowy Mountains rodeo celebrates 80 years

image.altText: A white woman, auburn hair, dark blue dress walking through green garden, pearl necklace.

props.synopsis: Former Darwin councillor Paul Arnold was found guilty of domestic violence after a years-long court battle, with his ex-partner refusing to be scared into silence. She said the case was "stressful and deeply humiliating", but facing her abuser had been empowering.

title.children: 'Evidence spoke louder' than abusive ex's lies in years-long court battle

image.altText: Two police officers standing next to a smashed up car.

props.synopsis: DFAT is supporting the families of a NSW Central Coast man killed and a woman injured in a scooter crash in Bali.

title.children: One Australian dead, another badly injured after Bali scooter crash

image.altText: A close up of a woman holding a photograph of three young women

props.synopsis: An Australian woman is believed to have become the first person in the world to donate organs after self-administering oral voluntary assisted dying medication.

title.children: World-first organ donation after mum self-administers VAD medication

image.altText: A group of people standing together indoors, with several holding bottles with sparklers in them. Flames are visible nearby

props.synopsis: The prevalence of sparklers at a Swiss ski resort bar where dozens of people died in a fire this week has been branded "irresponsible", as authorities probe potential compliance issues there.

title.children: 'Irresponsible': Sparklers and venue become focus of Swiss bar blaze probe

image.altText: A photo of a woman with burns on her face

props.synopsis: Rachel Dear has a serious warning for anyone using a gas barbecue after she suffered significant face and body burns while cooking on Christmas Eve.

title.children: Mum's urgent BBQ warning after suffering face, body burns

image.altText: red electrical light in the sky

props.synopsis: A storm chaser says he "screamed" when he captured an elusive natural phenomenon, known as red sprites, on video.

title.children: 'I just screamed': Storm chaser captures rare red sprites in WA sky

image.altText: Anthony Albanese

props.synopsis: What are you watching in Australian politics in 2026? That's the question we put to the ABC's political journalists and columnists.

title.children: Political outlook 'dramatically shifted' after Bondi

image.altText: grok

props.synopsis: The generative AI chatbot integrated with X is under international scrutiny after reports it was filling the social media platform with sexually explicit images of children and women.

title.children: Grok under fire over complaints it let users undress minors in photos

image.altText: The surf safety message is going beyond "swim between the flags".

props.synopsis: Every summer, millions of Australians head to the beach and every year thousands are rescued by lifeguards or surf life savers, and even surfers or other bystanders.

title.children: Red and yellow flags can be confusing. Is it time to change them?

image.altText: An image of a secluded beach on a sunny day.

props.synopsis: The man was pulled unresponsive from the water at a remote beach south of Wollongong after he was tangled in a float line.

title.children: NSW drownings toll rises after desperate attempts to save spearfisher

image.altText: Percy Island aerial

props.synopsis: Middle Percy Island is a rare gem where boaties can come ashore and wander through thousands of mementos left by travellers from across the globe.

title.children: A 'haven' for sailors on Queensland's coast, with tales of hidden treasure

image.altText: A pile of squashed coffee pods in a bin at Nowra.

props.synopsis: Between 10 and 20 per cent of the 3 million coffee pods Australians consume daily are actually recycled. Here's what's being done to change that.

title.children: Millions of coffee pods go to landfill. Here's what is being done about it

image.altText: Xi Jinping

props.synopsis: The US has no intention of abandoning Taiwan. But it also has no intention of binding itself to an automatic war commitment on a timeline it does not control.

title.children: Two truths and a lie: Inside the China-Taiwan-US triangle
